definition: abbr. for 尺有所短，寸有所長|尺有所短，寸有所长[chi3 you3 suo3 duan3 , cun4 you3 suo3 chang2]
a Chinese foot/one-third of a meter/a ruler/a tape-measure/one of the three acupoints for measuring pulse in Chinese medicine/CL:支[zhi1],把[ba3]
one of the characters used to represent a musical note in gongche notation, 工尺譜|工尺谱[gong1 che3 pu3]
short/brief/to lack/weak point/fault
a unit of length/inch/thumb
length/long/forever/always/constantly
chief/head/elder/to grow/to develop/to increase/to enhance
person narrow-minded and shortsighted
lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
keenly observant of trivial details
cow and famous steed at the same trough (idiom); fig. the common and the great are treated alike
see 方枘圓鑿|方枘圆凿[fang1 rui4 yuan2 zao2]
lit. to argue who is right and wrong (idiom); to quibble/a storm in a teacup
a thousand tries leads to one success (idiom, humble expr.); Even without any notable ability on my part, I may still get it right sometimes by good luck.
to correct in the evening a fault of the morning (idiom)/to quickly amend one's ways
clay ox, wooden horse (idiom); shape without substance/worthless object
to judge people based on their success or failure (idiom)
Sima Xiangru is meticulous and Mei Gao is fast (idiom)/to each his good points
lit. for some things a foot may be too short, and for the other an inch will suffice (proverb)/fig. everyone has their strong and weak points/everything has its advantages and disadvantages
pinyin: chi3 you3 suo3 duan3 , cun4 you3 suo3 chang2

definition: Words of benevolence apply universally (idiom). Humanitarian expressions benefit all.
Men of Zheng fighting over their respective ages (idiom)/a futile quarrel
to bear one's own responsibilities and not pass them to others (idiom)
burning beanstalks to cook the beans (idiom); to cause internecine strife
